title: Quiz 3: Movement & Specimen Collection
description: Assess skills in lifting/transferring patients and collecting blood, urine, and swab specimens.

questions.question: Which of the following principles should be observed when lifting or transferring a patient? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Keep the back straight and bend the knees
Maintain a wide base of support
Hold the patient close to your body
Pull the patient across linens to reduce friction

questions.explanation: Use leg muscles (not back), keep weight close, wide base. Do NOT pull (causes friction); roll or push instead.
questions.hint: Think about body mechanics and skin integrity.

questions.question: Order the steps for transferring a patient from bed to a chair:

items.text: Place chair parallel to the head of the bed
Help patient to a sitting position on side of bed
Allow patient to sit a few seconds to check for faintness

questions.explanation: Prepare equipment -> Sit patient up -> Assess stability -> Dress feet -> Transfer.

questions.question: When collecting a 24-hour urine specimen, what should be done with the FIRST voided urine at the start time (e.g., 6:00 AM)?

options.text: Send it separately to the lab
Use it to rinse the container

questions.explanation: The first voiding is discarded to start the 24-hour cycle with an empty bladder. All subsequent urine is collected.
questions.hint: Does the clock start with a full or empty bladder?

questions.question: Match the specimen collection method with the correct procedure:

pairs.right: Clean genitals, discard first flow, collect middle
Depress tongue, say 'Ah', sweep inflamed area
Early morning, deep cough, not saliva
Prick finger, wipe first drop, collect next drops

questions.explanation: Midstream avoids contamination; Throat swab targets inflammation; Sputum must come from lungs; Malaria slide needs fresh capillary blood.
questions.hint: Think about where the specimen comes from.

questions.question: When taking a throat swab, you should firmly touch the tongue and uvula to ensure a good sample.
questions.explanation: You should gently but firmly sweep over the inflamed area (tonsils/pharynx) taking care NOT to touch the tongue with the swab.
questions.hint: Touching the tongue might cause gagging or contamination.

questions.question: A ___BLANK___ specimen is best collected in the early morning prior to cleaning the mouth or eating.
questions.explanation: Sputum accumulates overnight and is most concentrated/abundant in the early morning.

questions.question: What is the recommended method to move a helpless patient from a bed to a stretcher?

options.text: Dragging the patient by the arms
Using a three-carrier lift or a draw sheet
Having the patient roll over the gap
Lifting the patient by the waist

questions.explanation: A three-carrier lift or using a sheet under the patient is safest for both patient and staff.
questions.hint: It requires multiple people or a sheet.

questions.question: In a malaria blood slide preparation, why is the first drop of blood wiped away?
questions.explanation: The first drop contains tissue fluid which may dilute the sample or affect the results.

questions.question: When collecting a High Vaginal Swab (HVS), the speculum should be lubricated with antiseptic jelly.
questions.explanation: The speculum should be lubricated with sterile warm water. Jelly/antiseptics may interfere with test results (especially Pap smears or cultures).
questions.hint: What might kill the bacteria you are trying to find?

questions.question: Which position is a female patient placed in for a High Vaginal Swab or pelvic examination?
questions.explanation: Lithotomy position (heels together, knees apart) provides best access for pelvic/genital exams.
